microstructure: single BCC phase; BCC (Ti, Nb, Ta)-rich matrix and HCP (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates after hot forging
evidence: The hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy has a high compressive yield strength of 1740 MPa with a considerable compressive ductility of 12% at room temperature.

microstructure: dual phase structure with BCC and HCP phases
evidence: The micro-hardness and Young's modulus are 763 HV and 139GPa, respectively, for the as-sintered alloy. As for the hot-forged alloy, the indentation of the matrix and the precipitates show a substantial difference in the size. The micro-hardness and Young's modulus are 579 HV and 120GPa for the matrix, respectively, while those for the precipitates are 1216 HV and 172GPa, respectively. The HCP (Zr, Al)-rich phase is much harder than the BCC phase, which indicates that the (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates can act as a strengthening phase in the RHEA. The compression behavior of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy is shown in Fig.  5 . The stress-strain curve presents a good combination of strength and plasticity. The mechanical properties of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy are as follows: σ 0.2 = 1740 MPa, σ m = 2031 MPa, and δ = 12% at room temperature. In view of the low density (7.3 g/ cm 3 determined by Archimedes method), the hot-worked TiNb-Ta 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy has a high specific strength.

microstructure: BCC matrix and HCP (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates
evidence: The hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 RHEA has a high compressive yield strength of 1740 MPa with a considerable compressive plasticity of 12% at room temperature. The precipitation strengthening and the grain-boundary strengthening contribute about 51% and 35% to the strength increment, respectively.

microstructure: uniform deformation, microcracks at the precipitates
evidence: Fig. 6. Microstructures of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy after compression: (a) low magnification shows uniform deformation (b) high magnification image shows microcracks at the precipitates.
